brief_description: Phase 1,single-arm study testing whether islet transplantation procedures and results from a previous study conducted in Edmonton, Canada, can be repeated.
brief_title: Shapiro ITN005CT:  Islet Transplantation in Type 1 Diabetic Patients
description: The transplanting of islet cells has been studied in Type 1 diabetic patients whose blood sugar levels will not stay normal, despite intensive insulin therapy. A recent study conducted in Edmonton, Canada, was able to demonstrate that islet transplantation led to insulin independence in a majority of the patients treated. This study extends the results obtained from the Edmonton study, which used islet transplantation in Type 1 diabetic patients with steroid-free immunosuppression.
endpoints: Change in mean C-peptide Area Under the Curve (AUC) response to a Mixed Meal Tolerance Test (MMTT) between Baseline (pre-treatment) and Month 24
hypothesis: Does anti-CD3 mAb treatment halt the progression of newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes
objectives: Blood glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level less than 6.5 percent, blood glucose level post overnight fast not to exceed 140mg per dL and 2 hour postprandial blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL
official_title: Islet Transplantation in Type1 Diabetic Patients Using the Edmonton Protocol of Steroid free Immunosuppression (ITN005CT)

arm.description: Portal vein islet transfusions with sirolimus, tacrolius, daclizumab
arm.name: Islet Transplantation

personnel.organization: University of Alberta, Clinical Islet Transplant Program
